;香港地铁公司将在未来投资 650 亿港元（83.1 亿美元）五年来更新和维护铁路资产，标志着年度支出增加了 30%，同时在一系列事故导致罚款和服务中断后进一步采用创新和技术来提高标准。

;

;

; p>;11月，一列火车驶入油麻地站时被铁轨旁脱落的金属围栏撞到，车门被撕裂，一节车厢出轨。荃湾线部分路段服务中断数小时，乘客在交通停止前通过紧急出口离开车厢并在黑暗中沿着轨道行走时处于危险之中。

;香港海关在发现 1400 万港元（180 万美元）后逮捕了三名男子从荷兰运往该市的一批木桌中隐藏了价值 32 公斤的毒品。

;

;32 公斤（70 磅）的氯胺酮被隐藏在三个 15 厘米（6 英寸）厚的桌子的空心中心香港海关周三表示，每件长约 2 米 x 1.5 米（6.5 英尺 x 5 英尺），重约 50 公斤。

;

;海关毒品调查局高级督察杨伟汉说这批货物是上周从阿姆斯特丹运抵该市的一个海运集装箱中存放的 10 多批不同货物中的一批。元朗一家物流公司。

;

;“X光检查显示，违禁药物藏在三张镂空的木桌里，”高级督察说。

;

;杨说他们在这批货物中发现了 32 公斤的氯胺酮，这批货物的市值估计为 1,400 万港元。

;

;伪装成工人的人员运送了这批货物，但被指示将其留在元朗的一个室外停车场周一下午。

;

;一群便衣警察在停车场附近等候了六个多小时，直到晚上 9 点左右，两名男子才出现来接走货物。

;

;在星期一的行动中，他们逮捕了这两名男子和停车场的保安人员，据称他们担任了望。

;

;这三名年龄在 30 至 52 岁之间的男子因涉嫌贩运危险药物而被拘留– 最高可判处终身监禁和罚款 500 万港元的罪行。

;

;杨说，初步调查表明，查获的毒品是打算运往该市的地下市场。

;

;今年迄今海关人员缉获的氯胺酮总量已超过400公斤。与 2022 年前六个月没收的近 300 公斤毒品相比，这一数字增长了 33%。

;

;香港警方查获价值 360 万港元的非法毒品，包括氯胺酮

;< p>;有消息称，今年查获的氯胺酮大部分是从荷兰、波兰、英国等欧洲国家空运进港的。并表示将加强与内地及海外执法机构的查验和情报交流，打击跨境贩毒。

;

;4月，海关人员在机场查获50公斤价值23港元的氯胺酮来自波兰的空运货物价值 100 万美元。

;

;香港警方检获价值 1.15 亿港元的毒品——一些夹在饼干里

;

;临时数字显示，香港警方检获了 5 种主要毒品城市——可卡因、大麻、甲基苯丙胺、海洛因和氯胺酮——在今年 1 月至 3 月期间从 2022 年同期的 797 公斤增加了 142% 至 1,929 公斤。

;

;氯胺酮的缉获量增加了 190%从 2022 年第一季度的 60 公斤增加到今年前三个月的 174 公斤。

;

;其中包括 354 部儿童性虐待内容的视频，其中的儿童年龄不超过 12 岁。

;救援人员使用声纳搜索失踪的泰坦尼克号潜水器，发现船上有五人在水下媒体报道援引美国政府的消息称，两天前飞机在北大西洋消失时发出“砰砰”声。

;

;参与搜索的一架加拿大 P-8 飞机“每天都在该地区听到砰砰声” 30分钟。四小时后，部署了额外的声纳，但仍能听到砰砰声，”据滚石杂志报道，一封发给美国国土安全部官员的内部电子邮件说。

;

;CNN 还报道说，声纳接收到砰砰声，根据美国政府的一份内部备忘录，但该文件没有说明周二听到噪音的时间、持续了多长时间或可能导致噪音的原因。

;

;7.7 米长的 Titan 是为了根据其规格，在水下停留 96 小时——让五名船员一直待到美国东部标准时间星期四早上（香港时间星期四晚上），然后空气耗尽。

;

;一名飞行员和四名乘客很早就进入了微型潜艇周日，它在进行了两小时的潜水后大约 1 小时 45 分钟与水面的母船失去了联系。

;

;随着加拿大和美国当局加强搜索，之前关于安全设计和其所有者美国 OceanGate Expeditions 开发的潜水器被曝光。

;

;泰坦尼克号是一艘英国远洋班轮，于 1912 年 4 月在其处女航中撞上冰山并沉没，其残骸位于位于马萨诸塞州科德角以东约 1,450 公里（900 英里）和纽芬兰圣约翰以南 644 公里处。

;

;失踪的泰坦尼克号潜艇的老板曾称他的行业“非常安全”

;

;美国海岸警卫队队长杰米弗雷德里克周二在新闻发布会上告诉记者，美国和加拿大的飞机已经搜索了超过 19,000 平方公里的公海，面积比康涅狄格州还大。

;

;加拿大军方已经弗雷德里克说，他们放下声纳浮标以聆听可能来自泰坦的任何声音，一艘配备遥控深水潜水器的商船也在该地点附近搜索。

;

;另外，一艘法国研究船载有Ifremer 研究所表示，应美国海军的要求，它自己的深海潜水机器人船被派往搜索区域，预计将于当地时间周三晚上抵达。

;

;泰坦号上的游客每人花费 250,000 美元的探险队包括 58 岁的英国亿万富翁 Hamish Harding 和 48 岁的巴基斯坦出生的商人 Shahzada Dawood 及其 19 岁的儿子 Suleman，他们都是英国公民。

;

;法国探险家据报道，现年 77 岁的 Paul-Henri Nargeolet 和 OceanGate Expeditions 的创始人兼首席执行官 Stockton Rush 也在船上。当局尚未确认任何乘客的身份。

;

;据专家称，救援人员在寻找泰坦号和拯救船上人员方面都面临重大障碍。

;

;失踪的泰坦尼克号船员游览潜水器？

;

;伦敦大学学院海洋工程教授阿利斯泰尔·格雷格 (Alistair Greig) 表示，如果潜水器在潜水中途遇到紧急情况，飞行员很可能会释放配重浮回水面。他说，但由于缺乏沟通，在浩瀚的大西洋中定位一辆货车大小的潜水器可能具有挑战性。

;

;潜水器从外部用螺栓密封，即使它浮出水面，也能防止乘员在没有帮助的情况下逃生。

;

;如果泰坦号在海底，由于海面以下 3 公里以上的极端条件，救援工作将更具挑战性。泰坦尼克号位于水下 3,810 米（12,500 英尺）处，阳光无法穿透。

;

;只有专门的设备才能到达如此深度而不会被巨大的水压压垮。

;

;“这真是有点像宇航员进入太空，”泰坦尼克号专家蒂姆·马特林说。 “我认为如果它在海底，那么能够潜到那么深的潜艇就很少了。因此，我认为几乎不可能实现潜艇之间的救援。”

;

;旅游潜艇的船体设计承受如此深度的能力在 2018 年的诉讼中受到质疑OceanGate 的前海事运营总监大卫·洛克里奇 (David Lochridge) 提交了一份文件，他说他在提出对该船的安全担忧后被解雇了。

;

;OceanGate 在对 Lochridge 的违约诉讼中表示，他不是工程师，他拒绝接受首席工程师的保证，并指责他不当分享机密信息。双方于 2018 年 11 月达成和解。

;

;该公司没有回应路透社的置评请求，其 Lochridge 案的律师 Thomas Gilman 拒绝置评。 Lochridge 的律师拒绝置评，只是说：“我们祈祷每个人都能安全返回”。

;

;在诉讼前几个月，一群潜水器行业领导者写信给 OceanGate，警告“实验性”方法”据《纽约时报》报道，对潜艇的开发进行干预可能会导致“轻微到灾难性”的问题。

;

;造成 1,500 多人死亡的泰坦尼克号沉没事件已在书籍和电影中永垂不朽，包括1997 年的轰动一时的电影《泰坦尼克号》重燃了大众对沉船的兴趣。

;

;“澳大利亚人一看到公路勇士就认得他们，”乌克兰国防部早些时候说本月在社交媒体上发布的一段视频中，敦促澳大利亚派遣更多坦克。

;在描绘反乌托邦澳大利亚战争的疯狂麦克斯电影中的镜头中播放摇滚音乐，该视频强调了新的推动力总理安东尼·艾博年 (Anthony Albanese) 的政府将在基辅与俄罗斯庞大的军队对抗时加大支持力度。

;

;一个重要的统计数据未被提及：在西方发达国家中，澳大利亚是对乌克兰贡献最小的国家之一，尽管它是乌克兰的主要间接经济受益者

;

;根据彭博经济研究院的计算，自莫斯科发动入侵以来的 15 个月里，能源和其他大宗商品价格的飙升为澳大利亚带来了约 1500 亿澳元（1020 亿美元）的出口繁荣前政府经济学家詹姆斯·麦金太尔 (James McIntyre)。

;

;然而，该国向乌克兰提供的军事和人道主义援助相当于意外收获的 0.5%，低于波兰、捷克共和国和丹麦给了。这促使澳大利亚的保守派反对派和学术界要求政府给予更多支持。

;

;“做正确的事”：澳大利亚敦促中国不要向俄罗斯提供武器

;

;“有澳大利亚被视为战略旁观者的风险——我们谈得很好，但我们实际上并没有做太多实际的事情，”堪培拉澳大利亚战略政策研究所的高级分析师马尔科姆·戴维斯说。 “这真的取决于澳大利亚政府的行动。”

;

;国防部长理查德马勒斯本月早些时候驳斥了澳大利亚做得不够的说法，他在接受采访时表示，该国是最大的贡献者在美国以外的印太地区。

;

;“整个欧洲都明白，乌克兰自己也明白，澳大利亚正在竭尽全力支持乌克兰，”兼任副总理的马尔斯说， 6 月 3 日说。

;乌克兰希望从澳大利亚、加拿大、挪威和瑞典等军事强国获得更多致命援助和补充火力。

;

;虽然澳大利亚本身也提供军事援助可能对改变战场影响不大，但它有助于保持武器流向基辅，并可能鼓励韩国等其他国家，韩国正在权衡是否开始向弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基总统的政府提供武器。

;虽然澳大利亚正在在世界的另一端，它从一开始就受到莫斯科对其邻国的军事行动的影响，2014 年，当俄罗斯分裂分子在乌克兰东部击落马来西亚航空公司 17 号航班时，有 38 名其公民丧生。

;

;上个月的预算没有提供任何额外资金来支持乌克在给马勒斯和外交部长黄英贤的信中说，敦促他们加大支持力度。 “其他非北约捐助者现在越来越多地掩盖澳大利亚的支持。”

;乌克兰对《疯狂的麦克斯》视频的呼吁“非常聪明、绝妙”，ASPI 的戴维斯说。 “他们采用了一段澳大利亚民间传说，并用它来表明他们正处于为生存而战的关键阶段，他们确实需要帮助。”

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 13:20:01 +0800 UN climate talks: ‘lack of trust’, funding stymie progress between China-backed nations and Westhttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3224745/un-climate-talks-lack-trust-funding-stymie-progress-between-china-backed-nations-and-west?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.21 12:00;
;;

;在最近的气候变化谈判中，中国支持的发展中国家与富裕的西方国家之间的争执不断升级in Germany hosted by the United Nations has dealt a significant blow to plans for accelerated action to slow the rate of global temperature increases.

;

;Rather than giving shape to mechanisms to accelerate the reduction of carbon emissions and enhance countries' ability to adapt to climate change, 11 days of technical talks which ended on Thursday last week were undermined by “process issues delaying action and a lack of trust between countries”, said Fernanda de Carvalho, global climate and energy policy lead of the WWF.

;

;“This doesn't match the urgency and the need for rapid and deep cuts in emissions highlighted by science.”

;

;The European Union's Copernicus climate change observatory reported on Thursday that the increase in average global temperatures since the advent of industrialisation had briefly exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) in early June.

;

;Climate activists said this demonstrated that existing pledges to reduce carbon emissions would fall far short of constraining the rise in average post-industrial temperature to 1.5 degrees by 2030, the target set under the UN climate change conference's 2015 Paris agreement.

;

;The world is currently on course to suffer average temperature increases of between 2.5 to 2.8 degrees , according to the latest assessments.

;

;The 1.5 degree-target is still achievable, however, because solar, wind and other renewable energy technologies are capable of taking over from fossil fuels, thereby reducing carbon emissions.;

;But with the cost of the transition estimated at about US$1 trillion by 2030, negotiations in Bonn between the wealthy Global North and developing Global South were dominated by arguments over who should be responsible for financing a “just transition” to a clean energy-powered economy.

;

;'We will face a water crisis': Malaysia makes it rain – by seeding clouds

;

;The EU and its mostly Western allies pushed for the inclusion of a mitigation work programme in the conference's agenda that would require countries to commit to greater reductions in carbon emissions.

;

;Developed countries taking part in the Bonn conference also called on major emerging economies China and India – classified as developing nations by the UN – to do more to cut emissions and contribute to loss-and-damage funds.

;

;The Group of 77 coalition of developing nations plus China responded by demanding that the agenda also include the establishment of a stand -alone loss-and-damage fund to compensate developing countries for climate change impacts.

;

;Backed by most other developing nations taking part, the proposal called for a new loss-and-damage fund that would be independent of existing climate-finance funds, and be financed by grants rather than loans from wealthy nations in recognition of their historic responsibility for the bulk of greenhouse gases emitted since the 1850s.

;

;Western-led parties balked at this proposal and accused developing nations' groups of impeding progress in the negotiations.

;

;In turn, developing nations reminded the Global North that they had not yet fulfilled the commitment they made in 2009 to mobilise US$100 billion a year by 2020 to support action on climate change by developing nations.

;

;“There are fundamental geopolitical fault lines we will have to address if we're able to accelerate climate action,” said Tom Evans, a policy adviser on climate diplomacy and geopolitics for E3G, an environmental think tank based in London.

;

;“At its core, multilateral climate action requires trust and cooperation,” he said, but “trust has been eroded” by unkept promises on climate finance.

;

;'People fear venturing out': dozens die as intense heat sweeps northern India

;

;Scores of developing countries demanding grants to support their adaptation to clean energy already face unsustainable levels of debt, with government budgets depleted from the Covid-19 pandemic, and the high costs of capital deterring investment, he said.

;

;“It's critical that developed countries address core issues like these”, which were barriers to the economic development of lower- and middle-income countries, Evans said.

;

;Investing in “just climate transitions in the Global South” was a key step to “rebuilding trust and practically demonstrating that the shift to clean energy” was the development model of the future, he said.

;

;Amid the bickering in Bonn, an agreement on the agenda of the technical talks was only reached on the penultimate day.

;

;It did not include the West-proposed emissions mitigation work programme, and lacked any specifics on the stand-alone loss-and-damage fund called for by developing nations.

;

;The lack of progress in the technical talks threatens to undermine the success of the COP 28 UN climate summit in Dubai at the end of the year, which is widely seen as the last chance for ramped-up global action to meet the 2030 target for temperature increases.

;

;“We're looking at two opposite ends of a scale that is in perpetual imbalance,” said Haneea Isaad, an energy finance analyst of the Institute of Energy Economics and Financial Analysis, a US think tank.

;

;The Global North in the wake of its development had “left the world polluted and prone to natural disasters” while the Global South “bears the brunt of this”, she said.

;President Joe Biden said his administration wants to ensure that artificial intelligence systems are safe before they reach the public as he met business leaders and experts to discuss new safeguards for the emerging technology.

;

;“In seizing this moment, we need to manage the risks to our society, to our economy and our national security,” Biden said in San Francisco on Tuesday. He said he was committed to “making sure AI systems are safe before they are released”.

;

;The president reiterated his calls for Congress to pass bipartisan privacy legislation.

;

;“Social media has already shown us the harm that powerful technology can do without the right safeguards in place. That's why I said in the State of Union that the Congress needs to pass bipartisan privacy legislation to impose strict limits on personal data collection, ban targeted advertising to our children, and require companies to put health and safety first,” Biden said.

;

;Will ChatGPT and similar generative AI tools worsen China's job crisis?

;

;The administration is pushing companies to develop new privacy and security protections for consumers as the use of technologies such as generative AI has exploded in recent months.

;

;Those meeting with Biden included Sal Khan, the CEO of Khan Academy Inc; Common Sense Media CEO Jim Steyer; Tristan Harris, executive director of the Center for Humane Technology; Oren Etzioni, former CEO of the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence; Fei-Fei Li, co-director of Stanford University's Human-Centered AI Institute; Joy Buolamwini，算法正义联盟创始人； Jennifer Doudna, a professor of chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley; and Stanford political science professor Rob Reich.

;

;White House Chief of Staff Jeff Zients is overseeing efforts to develop additional steps the administration can take on AI in the coming weeks, according to a White House official.

;

;Zients earlier this month said AI companies are working with the administration to unveil privacy and security commitments in the near future, an effort spurred by worries that the ongoing regulatory process may work too slow to address emerging technologies.

;

;Biden on Tuesday said that Vice-President Kamala Harris next month would convene civil rights and consumer protection groups to discuss AI concerns.

;

;The administration's effort has also sought to enlist major AI players.

;

;Biden and Harris met in May at the White House with the leaders of top firms, including CEOs Sam Altman of OpenAI Inc, Dario Amodei of Anthropic, Microsoft Corp's Satya Nadella and Sundar Pichai of Alphabet Inc.

;

;Companies, including Microsoft and Alphabet's Google, have committed to participating in the first independent public evaluation of their systems. But the administration is also seeking a broader regulatory push. The Commerce Department said earlier this year it was considering rules that could require AI models to go through a certification process before release.

;

;Will AI be China's ace in the hole to surpass the US and become the top economy?

;

;The Federal Trade Commission says it's also monitoring the use of artificial intelligence tools and the technology has attracted the scrutiny of Congress.

;

;Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer on Wednesday will deliver an address at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington outlining “his vision for how the Senate can harness AI's potential and protect our society from its potential harms”, according to a statement from his office.

Ambitious bids desirable but leadership needed to drive interest, investment, scientists sayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3224813/hong-kong-moonshot-projects-ambitious-bids-desirable-leadership-needed-drive-interest-investment?utm_source=rss_feed

;Ambitious scientific bids by Hong Kong could lure talent to the city but it would take leadership to drive interest and investment for such projects to take off, according to experts.

;

;Scientists and researchers chimed in after Alibaba Cloud founder Wang Jian on Tuesday floated a “moonshot” idea for the city to set up a cloud-based research hub for astronomers from around the world to make discoveries based on imagery captured by the yet-to-be-launched Chinese Survey Space Telescope.

;

;Wang, who made the suggestion at the Post's China Conference: Hong Kong 2023, said such a project would be a magnet for top talent and spawn innovations with great potential even if the initial idea itself held limited economic benefits.

;

;The telescope, also known as Xuntian, is set to be put into use next year and will boast a 2.5 billion-pixel camera that has a field of view 300 times greater than the Hubble Space Telescope, allowing scientists to map up to 40 per cent of the skies.

;

;The China Manned Space Agency has set up four research centres across the nation in anticipation of the Xuntian launch. Four tertiary institutions from the city, including the University of Hong Kong (HKU) and Polytechnic University (PolyU), are involved in the Zhuhai-based centre established in 2019.

;

;Quentin Parker, an HKU astrophysicist and director of its Laboratory for Space Research, said it would not be too late for Hong Kong to start its own hub.

;

;“It would be fantastic if Hong Kong has its moonshot project. We do have the talent, we do have the reputation as a global tertiary education mini-superpower,” said Parker, adding that there were about 20 astrophysicists across the city's institutions.

;

;Making Wang's vision a reality would require investment in the form of government funding or private-sector donations to direct the attention of university leadership to the field, he said, noting that medical science had attracted the bulk of such donations at HKU.

;

;“What would be good to build belief would be for somebody, perhaps like Wang Jian, to put in a HK$10 million professorship for space science research at HKU. That would kickstart interest, brand and profile, and show that people care about this area,” Parker said.

;

;An indication of support by the government for local astrophysics research would also be helpful, he added.“It is feasible. It depends on the will, it depends on the opportunity, it depends on the leadership.”

;

;Hong Kong leader calls on technology and education sectors to cultivate talent

;

;Professor Christopher Chao, vice-president for research and innovation at PolyU, agreed that Hong Kong's best moonshot opportunity would be taking part in China's astronomy projects.

;

;Chao, who joined the Chief Executive's Policy Unit Expert Group last month, said Hong Kong had also undertaken some major space projects, citing PolyU as an example. He said the university had been a part of a number of mainland large-scale projects such as moon exploration, sampling of rocks and soil from the moon and the nation's first Mars mission.

;

;“Moonshot could mean extremely large-scale projects, which are beyond the scope of the Earth or things beside us,” he said.

;

;“We have already joined some of our country's moon and Mars exploration missions. This can be the foundation to allow us to continue doing so. This can serve as Hong Kong's moonshot projects.”

;

;“For example, for the moon exploration mission, we had to develop many advanced and precise devices that involve electronic and mechanical parts,” Chao said. “These parts can also be utilised in surveying places such as water conduits.”
